text: (upbeat music)

- Lena, thank you so much
for joining us today.
- You're welcome.
Thank you for having me.
- So if you'd be so kind
just please talk a little bit

about your your career at
MongoDB and your role there.
- So, I'm the CISO.
I'm the first CISO there.

I've been the first CISO at
my, this is 1, 2, 3 jobs now,
which is awesome 'cause I'm not stepping
into anyone else's shoes.

I think CJ is doing a
marvelous job of stepping

into Steve Schmitz very
large, hard to fill shoes.
So hat's off to him.

I've been extremely lucky
in being the first CISO
at the Power Authority where I worked

in critical infrastructure,
then in FinTech,
and then I finally at MongoDB.

So it's a lot of fun 'cause
you make your own rules,

but you're the one throat to
choke, which I don't mind.
That's one of the reasons I took the job.

So I've been there for about
three and a half years.
When I started, there was a really good
security presence in place.

It just wasn't under that
one umbrella, that panacea.
And to be honest, I didn't walk around
and say everyone with the word security
in their job title now reports to me.
I wanted to get the lay of the land
and I'm still, the land is ever shifting

and I'm still looking
at the lay of the land

and I really do like the
separation that we have

of product security, cloud
security, server security,

and I talk regularly with
folks who run those systems
down to the engineering level,

up to the EVP level just to get
that feeling of where are we
and I really love that part of the job.
And then I'm also responsible
for governance risk and compliance.
So that's my second team.
Very distinct teams, but there's obviously

a lot of collaboration
and yeah, I love it.
And this is for anyone who knows me,
I'm absolutely passionate about what I do

and I've always said
the day that I wake up

and say I just wanna do this
anymore, I won't do it anymore.
- Fantastic. So over the last few years,

I think it's fair to say
that the role of the CISO

has evolved from being that
technical security expert
to really being a business leader.
So can you describe an opportunity
that you envisioned at MongoDB?

Were you able to solve a
business problem through

security risk compliance
or privacy programs?
- I'm always trying to see the big picture
and get it down into something that's,
someone mentioned recently eating
an elephant chunk by chunk.
So it's go and interest in compliance
sometimes it's like chunk by chunk.
And we basically took all of the controls
that we have to comply with
of which there are over I think 1200 now.

And we mapped them to
where we had evidence,
which we have evidence for all of them.
But what we tried to do was,

if one piece of evidence
serves for five controls
for five different qualifications
we only have to ask the question once
and they supply it five times.
And so that's what we've been doing
and we've now saved our engineering teams

probably 80% of the
time they used to spend

on showing me the screenshot
for the antivirus,
for this regulatory rule.

And they have a lot of respect
for what the GRC team did.
And I think that's a big business benefit
that engineering really appreciates
'cause everyone's time is valuable,

but they're the folks that
get the product out the door.
They get the patches in place,

they get the security
and they maintain it.

So the more time they
have to do their jobs

rather than giving me
evidence for compliance,
the better it is.
- And that's spot on.
So the less time that they're spending
on undifferentiated work,

they can actually add
value back to the business,

which I'm sure the larger
business appreciates.
- I think as well though,

with them seeing that we are
being proactive with their time

and we're being respectful
of what they do as engineers.

I think sometimes, and
this is just my opinion,
but I think sometimes engineering is like,
oh, they're just engineers.

Just throw them some
red meat and some code
and they'll be happy.
Our engineers are amazing bunch of people
and the more time they have to collaborate
and work with people like AWS is like,
that's a business profit for me.
- Absolutely.

- They're using their
time in an affordable

and a good manner and we're
getting so much more out of it
and my team's interested as well.
My team gets to see, they'll now meet

with the engineering person
for an hour instead of a day.

And that hour is productive
and it's enjoyable

'cause they can see later the
end of the tunnel, both teams.

- There's been a shift
in the last few years
as more companies have been adopting cloud
and investing in security as code
and much more of an engineering effort.

So security teams are
going from that point

and click console operations
to actually build and code

that will do things for
them in the cloud at scale.

Can you talk a little bit
about how you view that

and how you've implemented
that shift at MongoDB?
- So obviously we have specific tool sets

both from AWS and from
other third parties.

And I'm always very keen
to get a real feeling
of what my team has used before.
So obviously we're a new team,
we're a couple years old,

and getting all this new blood
has been super interesting

because people have used
stuff I've never heard of.

And it's like, okay,
show us what it can do.
And been able to share that knowledge
with our security champions,
with the other engineering teams,

the hardcore server
security engineering folks
who obviously security is always part
of their systems development lifecycle,
but they can now bounce real ideas

and really collaborate
with security engineers
who this is all they've done their life

and they love it and
they want to just imbue
the sense of we can really work together.
It doesn't have to be siloed.

And I think we've been really,
really, really successful

at breaking a lot of the
silos that occur everywhere.
I wouldn't say there was that many
when I started at MongoDB,
but I think any residual silos are gone,
which I think is rare.
- That's great to hear.
And I guess on that same track,
as CISOs we always have a limited amount
of security personnel that are actually
in the security department working for us
under our control and what we have to do,
because you can't hire a whole company

full of security engineers
is spread that knowledge
throughout the company,

make sure that you have
effectively security eyes
and ears throughout the business.

- CISOs we're a secretive
bunch of the best of times.
And so my role has been to really
get the word out there about security,

get people excited about it
as excited as I am anyway.

And just to like enjoy it
and don't be scared of it.

I've told my team, we're
not the team that says no
'cause sometimes you find that.
We're the team that says yes,

but here's the risk, here's
the cost, here's the ROI.
If we can give you it,
here's your business reason for doing it.
And by the way, here's the person

who's gonna be responsible
for it when it goes live.

So when you start bringing
money, responsibility,
accountability into the discussion
instead of just saying no,
people are like, oh, okay, you know what?
You've actually thought about this.

There's thoughtfulness
behind that leadership.
So yeah, okay, we're with you in this.
Let's work together for a solution.
And I'm making it sound

as though we live in this
perfect world, we don't.

We have people who say,
well, I wanna buy it

just because I'm that person
and I can just do what I want.
And I'm like, you know what?
Absolutely you can do that.
You're 100% responsible for it.

And by the way, you're now on
my risk register as a risk.
And then they're like,
oh, well, that's focused my mind a bit,
but maybe I don't need it that much.
- Well, that's spot on.

The idea of security
being a business partner
and stepping up to the plate,
that absolutely will support you,
but you have to understand the risks.

- Yeah. I mean there's
risks with everything,

but if you're introducing a
new tool set that requires
and you probably heard this,
oh, I need admin access to everything.
I need rules like, why?
For something that is marketing emails.

- So switching gears a little
bit to security operations
and security engineering a little bit.

How do you ensure with your
product teams at MongoDB

that security is considered
what I'll call early and often

in the development stage
so that any security issues

that pop up, you can
get them in dev or test

as opposed to the night before
it goes into production?
- Oh yeah, I mean security has been baked
into the SDLC for MongoDB
for way longer than I've been there.

We like to say MongoDB
Atlas is secure out the box.

We do everything that we can
to ensure that that is true.
And that goes back to having engineers
who understand security,

having that team mind to
bounce ideas off of it
if they have to.
There's no judgment.

Sometimes people can be a bit
judgy when it comes to code.

And being able to have
that open discussion

of, hey, we're seeing this,
should that be normal?

It's eyeopening to me that
people get into such a level,

a deep level of uncovering
possible security issues

and getting them way before
anybody would ever see them.

Not just this, I used to handle
some QA teams a few jobs ago
and it was always interesting

just the lobbing of
fire grenades above you.

QA to production, QA to
production, oh, back to dev now.
Oh, okay.
And you've got this hellish triangle
of just trying to get out the door,
whereas is here is very much
because it's built into the SDLC,

because it's run by
engineers for engineers.

There's so much fluff
has just been removed
from the whole process.

And our CTO, of course, Mark
Porter, technical genius.

I meet with him regularly
and I can talk to him.

He's got a team of experts in
his office of the CTO, OCTO,
including an ex-CISO, which I love
and I can bounce ideas off this person

and say, when you were a
CISO, what did you see?
Because I've never had that before.
I've never been able to talk to,
within my own company another CISO.
And so that was brilliant.
I mean, I love that.
I love that kind of relationship.

- So what drove that level
of security ownership
in the development teams then?
Is it just because we must build
and release a secure product?
But at the human factor,
if I'm a development engineer at MongoDB,
what drives me to make sure

that I'm releasing the
most secure code I can?

- I think basically, and
this is again my opinion,
it's the reputation that we have
for having the security out the box

and having so many options
to further secure it.
Queryable Encryption is out there now.

We have a product security
team that's just amazing

and again, staff by
engineers for engineers,
they get what they're talking about.
They're developers.
They come from a development background.

We just hired a new VP of
development productivity.

And this person's
responsibility is to cast a lens
over all of development.
What are they do?
Where can they, and I hate to sound
like a time and motion person

'cause I used to work in
a shipyard many years ago
and we these time and motion people
who would literally walk around

and measure how long it took
me to drink a cup of tea.
And I kind of joked with Tara

when I was speaking to them
last week about their job.

And I guess, they time me
when I'm at my cup of tea.

And they were like, nope,
couldn't be further from that.

It's basically talking
at a developer level
and an engineering level on how they feel
they can be more productive.

How can we get more product
as well out the door
in a more timely fashion?
'Cause everyone wants to be out the door

as quickly as possible, but
remaining securely as possible.
That's the important thing.
And that takes time.
There's always that trade off.
- That's a great story.

Lena, thank you so much
for joining us today.
- Thank you very much for having me.
